content.description:
Unique and beautiful. I found this route years ago. It had 6 bolts and some old pre-hung draws that were sun bleached and worn. There was a bail carabiner on the 6th bolt. I subsequently added two more lead bolts and a two bolt chain anchor taking the climb to the top of the wall. 

  Start off of crimps and move into a dish with side pulls. Bust right into pockets and up to 10 feet of crumbly rock. A difficult cryptic sequence gets you in to good rock and good holds. Climb to large huecos and a rest. Fire the bouldery crux past two bolts and left facing rail that takes you past two more bolts and the anchor. The rock is surprisingly good on this one for the GC. This is a proud lead and an unlikely climb given the nature of the rock in the GC.
content.location: Center left of the huge overhang. You'll know it when you see it. Its the only line of bolts up this section of wall.

content.description: Open book corner... Lots of wide climbing with some decent jams and face moves interspersed.
content.protection:
Single set with a few extra in the hand and larger sizes. 

  Build a natural anchor at the top. Could use a two bolt anchor.
content.location: The last climb on the wall at the end of the ledge.

content.description:
Beautiful dark face with nice features. Awkward start past a bolt to a ledge. Follow bolts up an interesting seam to thought provoking face moves. The rock is surprisingly good but a tad sharp.  

  Two Bolt anchor.
content.location: Around the corner from Warren Piece at the far end of the ledge.

content.description: Not much is known about this one The falcon guide has it as two pitches but it seems silly doing a 60 foot climb in two pitches. Supposedly there is fixed gear on this one. Belay is off a tree at the rim. With a two bolt anchor this could be a okay warm up.
content.protection: draws, cam and a few nuts.
content.location: Just past the exposed and narrow section of the access ledge norht of the gully.

content.description:
This is one of the steeper cracks at the crag. It protects with natural pro and didn't require bolts. 

  Make a few bouldery moves through an initial bulge with pro once you get higher. This takes you to a large ledge with a bush and some loose rock. Place in gear when you can and get set up underneath the roof with a crack that forms with pods of various sizes. Plug a few finger size cams and launch through the crux sequence to a good hand jam. Place a #1 camelot and climb easier thin hand crack to the anchor
content.protection:
Single set to #2 BD with some extras in the finger sizes. Make sure you place bomber pro in the pods before you launch through the crux bulge. If your gear rips your going to hit the ledge below.  

  Two bolt anchor. Can use the tree above to access anchor and set up top rope.
content.location: The right facing corner just left of Warren Piece.

content.description: North of the Medivac Wall this area is the Northern most section of climbing at the Bright Angle Walls. It is tucked away from the rim trail and therefore feels a little more secluded. The ledge that accesses the climbs has one narrow section where you need to pay attention. Once your reach the climbs the ledge is a wonderful perch to enjoy the evening light and climb some of the steepest lines of the area.
